title: MOF-associated complexes ensure stem cell identity and <italic>Xist</italic> repression
abstract: Histone acetyl transferases (HATs) play distinct roles in many cellular processes and are frequently misregulated in cancers. Here, we study the regulatory potential of MYST1-(MOF)-containing MSL and NSL complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and neuronal progenitors. We find that both complexes influence transcription by targeting promoters and TSS-distal enhancers. In contrast to flies, the MSL complex is not exclusively enriched on the X chromosome, yet it is crucial for mammalian X chromosome regulation as it specifically regulates <italic>Tsix</italic>, the major repressor of Xist lncRNA. MSL depletion leads to decreased <italic>Tsix</italic> expression, reduced REX1 recruitment, and consequently, enhanced accumulation of <italic>Xist</italic> and variable numbers of inactivated X chromosomes during early differentiation. The NSL complex provides additional, <italic>Tsix</italic>-independent repression of <italic>Xist</italic> by maintaining pluripotency. MSL and NSL complexes therefore act synergistically by using distinct pathways to ensure a fail-safe mechanism for the repression of X inactivation in ESCs.
